editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: THE HECTORS: OR THE FALSE CHALLENGE. A COMEDY Written in the Year, MDCLV.
LONDON, Printed for G. Bedel, and T. Collins, and are to be sold at their Shop at the Middle-Temple Gate in Fleet-streee 1656.

div.l: I'Ll not enquire why this All-knowing Age
Hath crop'd the Laurell, that adorn'd the Stage,
That Loooking-Glasse of Morals, whose reflex
Shew'd most their errors, whom it most did vex.
But this I'le say, who e're the Author be
Of this same piece, if't were my chance to see
Him; as I have this issue of his brain,
I'de beg the favour, that hee'd write again;
For till I read it from the self same pen,
Such height of Sense and Wit, I ne're agen
Shall hope to see; a strain (when read) you'l say,
(As many things now are) in a new way.
Here's Comick mirth, yet mix't with serious lines,
As if the Author had dig'd up the mines
Of Mercury and Plato, and cull'd thence
Their chiefest treasure, and would it dispense
In plain, though lively phrase. Here's no Courts, no Kings,
(I do suppose the Author thought such things
Not now in use.) And what is yet more rare,
Here is no dabling Poet, no nor bare,
Poor Belgick Captain; But what's most a wonder,
You shall but once read here Iove and Thunder;
No Academick wit, the Senses five,
Or Liber all Sciences not here contrive
Into a plot he doth, or wedding make
Upon Parnassus, or a storie take
From Lucian. I shall puzzle you, you'l cry,
What a deuce then can this play e're be? Why
It is—But stay, read it your selfe, and then
Judge rightly, and I'me sure you'l quit my pen.

list.item: LA-GULL A Gent. of a slender judgment, but of good means.

list.head: HECTORS.
list.item: HAD-LAND A Gent. of worth and courage, although of a decaied fortune.
Mrs. BUD A young Lass, newly come from School.
Mrs. PATE A cunning subtile Gentlewoman.

div.head: THE HECTORS: OR THE FALSE CHALLENGE.
ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Pate and Mrs. Lovewit.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: HE is indeed a pretty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lovewit.
sp.p: How well his dancing did become him!

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: He had a very handsome and unaffected way.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: His Discourse too (me thinks) I did extremely fancy, it was not too much starched with Formality, nor yet rudely loose.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: He was though in my mind somewhat too full of his Complements.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yet they were still so fitted to, and grounded on what was said, that he cannot but have a sudden and quick wit.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: He carried indeed the whole Entertainment through with an exceeding grace.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Some would have spent five times as much, yet forced our good natures in the end to have laughed at it. Prethee what is he?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Why do you not know, child of ignorance?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You know I came to th' Town but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: O it is true: And I pray you how do a • our friends in Surrey? My Cozen Norris? and Mrs. Nonesuch.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: They all desire to be remembred; but—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: How did my Cozen like the Stuff I bought her for her Gown?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very well. But prethee—

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I did the best I could to please her fancy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But what was that we were a talking of? O, of the Gentleman; what is he?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Why he i • one that lives here about the Town▪ of a fair Estate, his name is Welbred, he has now for some while been a servant of your Cozens.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Me thought he applyed himself much to her. Do • t think she ere will love him?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p:
Love him? How can she otherwise chuse? Th • re is not a La •• twix •
Lud-gate-hill and Westminster but is ready to run mad for him; at the first • ight he smites and ki • s, where e're he comes, there's none that can withstand him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But yet me thinks— But • rethee let us talk no more of him. Enter Mrs. Crisis and Mrs. Bud.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Stay, here is your Cozen: Prethee what Girle is that wi • h her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It is a friends Daughter of mine in the Country, that goeth to School here in London; she came up with me.
Affection! Where hast thou been? I have been looking for thee all over the house.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I your Affection, and you keep things so close from mee!

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: What things▪ I pray?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You need not make so strange, for I know all: there is a Lad, they say, that smites and kils where e're he comes, and you are she in whom he intends to finish all his Conquests.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Smite! and kil! Where e're he comes! Why, I hope, it is • ot the old bald fellow with the Sithe on his neck, old Monsieur Time? Smite, and kill! Strange, terrible words! What meanest thou?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I mean, he makes them talk or dream of him for a week, or so, or perhaps sigh or whine a little.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Hold there, as for talking or dreaming I am for you, but do you think I e're shall sigh for him? I know whom you mean.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Not I, as I live.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Spoke she but true!Aside.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And yet the man deserveth well, as men now are. He is (I must confesse) a handsom sprightful youth, well qualified in most things that become a Gentleman: and since it is my friends desire that I should marry, he is one (I think) I should not be ashamed in company to own for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O my unhappy fortune!Aside.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: The man I don't dislike, 'tis possible I might stay for a worse; and as possible, if I did stay, I might have a better, for I see nothing in him in which I could place my happiness.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No▪ Bu • how come we to talk of this Gentleman again?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Believe me, thou lovest him with a pretty indifferent love.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Her Love was certainly articled and agreed on by the old man her father. But let us find somewhat else to entertain the time withal. And now I think of it, what was that Gentlewoman who was there last night in the Sky coloured Satten Gown?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: O she is one of the great wits of the Town.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I thought so, yet Mr. Welbred put her shrewdly to it.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Her mind runs on nothing but Welbred, I think.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: They say that thou too (Affection) goest for a kind of Country wit, what e're thou ailest to be thus sober here.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sitting up so late last night hath somewhat disordered me, I confesse.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But as thou hopest to be married under thirty, think not of it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, I pray? for that is somewhat a terrible Conjuration.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why? A female wit is a strange prodigious kind of thing, it frights off all that have no wit, and they that have will never come on, except it be for an Afternoon or so, to exercise their tongues. I have been out of conceit with it ever since I heard a Gentleman say, that he was going to a Lady that I know, a reputed wit, to prepare him for a Visit to his Mistris. Fye upon it, a thing fit for nothing, but to make one a common courting stock. I hate the very thought of it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well then, if we must not think on them that have wit, let us think on them that have none: and first, how did you like the Gentleman that was there last night with the black curled hair:

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: With the black curled hair?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O, I know whom she means, it was a friend of that same Gentlewomans, she was here with him this morning to invite me to such another businesse to night. But why, I pray, dost thou take him to have no wit? Doth he pay all the Reckonings where e're he comes? Will he drink deep with a Lad that will keep a brace of Geldings and a Lacquey out of twenty pound a year? A dammee Captain, or an Oxford Majo • , and then game with them?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, I dare pass my word for him.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, these are the only modern fools.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, I cannot tell what you call a fool, (I must confesse) I am a little too young to be his Godmother, but yet me thinks, a dull and stupid thing (as I conceive him to be) should have a name.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: I am sure if he had had any thing in him, there was a Lady gave him a fair opportunity to shew it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Welbred would have paid her home.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I was a great while in doubt whether he could speak or no.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Well, I cannot tell,—for ought I know, he might serve with a good Jointure to boot; for my part, I saw him do nothing much absurd. And had you been here to day, you would have thought his silence last night, to have been more out of choice then any thing else.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: Really Cozen, there was a rare Gentleman in the slash'd doublet, and a button'd Cap, me thought he talk'd incomparably.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Whom doth she mean?

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Mr. Lagul certainly

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Alas poor soul!

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: Well, I must be going.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nay, prethee stay a little longer.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: No, I have appointed to meet one,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Who • Mr. Hadland, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Well, I hope when you come to lye at this end of the Town again, we shall more enjoy your company. Exit Pate.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O Mrs. Pate. Exeunt Lovewit and Bud after Pate.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: My Cozen too is certainly in love with him, for I have observed her mind all this day strangely musing, although sometimes it be disguised with some forced flashes of mirth: what e're is talked of, her thoughts still run on him, and then she will recal her self, not thinking that affected hiding shewes what else would ne're be mark'd.— 'Tis strange to see how generally this Gentleman doth take: For my part, as I see not any thing in him that I much mislike, so truly naught that I admire: He has (I must confesse) some graceful and becoming parts and qualities, a handsome way in talk; yet when I mark it seriously, me thinks it is as curious Pictures, which (although they make a pleasing shew, yet) for the most part are drawn on course and ordinary matter. I needs must say, he has this happinesse, that if he excel in ought, it is in things of that familiar nature, that each place and company he comes in, afford him opportunity to shew it. And this certainly is the only thing that makes him make a greater blaze then some of far more worth, whose eminence lying in that which is more choice, cannot so frequently discover it self, nor is their value prostituted unto every eye; but they, as great Bels, who are not easily nor on all slight occasions raised, yet being up, will far out sound any of these tinckling ting-tang blades.—Would heaven alot me but such a one to spend my time withal, it would be what I most desire; but yet I think I shall scarce run that odious fortune of a stale Maid in expectation of such a blessing. Enter Maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Mr. Welbred is come (forsooth) and desires to speak to you.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Carry him into the Dining Room, and tell him I will wait upon him presently. Exit Maid.
Stay, He will now set hard upon me, what shall I do? Yeeld? No, me thinks my fancy at this time doth not prompt me to it; I wil once more put him off, if handsomely I can. Exit.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: He will not out of my mind, but doth over rule my thoughts and force them to desires vaine and impossible: I impossible, for h • must needs fix on her, she is a Lady so without exception, of so fair a Fortune and such exquisite parts improved unto the height. He certainly then is hers; me thinks the very thought of that should be enough to master these desires; for usually Objects, though ne're so pleasing, if not probable, searce stir the mind; for since we all are rational, it were absurd our wills should act in vain. But on the contrary, when things with ease may be attained, we never give over until we are arrived at the utmost of our wishes. Thus nothing is more ordinary then for my Lady to love her Gentleman, or Mrs. Anne her fathers man. But if a Country Clowne coming up hither, and seeking for his Lawyer in Grayes Inne, should step into the Walks, and there should chance to spye some Master-piece of Nature, some fam'd Beauty, that for a time hath born the name, he would stand amazed, perhaps wish that his Ione were such, but farther would not be stirred, impossibility would stop more bold desires, and quench those sparks that else would turne to fires. But I without the remedy of hope, even in despair, begin a love that promiseth nought but grief and endlesse teares. But here he comes with my Cozen, I will stand and hear what they say. Enter Welbred and Crisis.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Come sweet Lady be no longer cruel, 'tis fit for vulgar common beauties to inhance the price of their Enjoyment by a long denyal; such Art were vain in you, and desperate in me, since I already am wound up unto the highest, and higher cannot go but break.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Must I answer to all this presently? that me thinks would bee the greatest inequality in the world; in all reason certainly I should have as much time as you had to study it.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Study it? He that is inspired doth not so little deliberate; I speak my very thoughts, on you my mind doth naturally run, nor can it vary, for Nature that hath in you raised Beauty to its highest pitch, outdone her own Idea's, hath thereby made you Commandresse of my soul, and all its passions and affects to wait on none but you; therefore seeing you have the power, O do no longer tyrranize.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, what now would you have me say?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What would I have you say? Can that be a question? Could your breath create me owner of the world, could I have diversity of woulds? Alas my thoughts are long since fixed on you, and my desires forgot all other Objects but your self.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: My self? then that is it you would have.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: O God,—Would have? I, above—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am lost, undone, undone:Within.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nay, pray now let me go, for you have me not yet, I must first chide you a little for this kind of language. What things do you think us women to be? Or rather, what would you have us our selves to fancy? For could I, me thinks, bu • look into the brest of some fond silly Gi • le, and see what thoughts she entertaines, by that time such a blade as you hath told her some such stories, that she gives Beauty being, and other faces to be accounted of as they partake of hers; that she can smite, wound, kill, • as if the fate of all mankind did hang upon her will, and twenty such things more, which if the poor thing have but wit enough to u • derstand, she is (without mercy) ruin'd, lost, undone.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Why I pray, Lady? for this is somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I'll warrant you I have a reason for what I say; for fi • st, she thinks her self somewhat (though what she cannot tell) that hath a just quarrel to Fate, that she can have nought but so poor a thing as man her mate; she fancies not this mean, she fancies not anothers Discourse, she hates this mans breeding, she hates anothers face, and for that coloured hair she refuseth a thousand pounds a year. Thus she continues for some years, until at the last, about some twenty nine, she doth begin to understand herself. But now the tide of Sutors and her beauty being eb'd, she stands a Fare for the next that comes; and in all haste she makes some desperate match, proves some old mans Nurse; perchance not so well, but Will her fathers man, her Taylor, or some Reformado Captain must serve her turne; or else (if she have any spirit) in a melancholy pet, she vowes a Virgin life, and for his sake that first deceived her, turnes man-hater. Come, come, in faith Sir you are to blame, were I now some kind of Lasse, forty to one but that I were meerely cozened of a good Husband.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Did one ever see such a plaguy Wench as this?— Aside. Not at all, Madam, are we to be blamed for what we are forced unto, such high flowne speeches are no more then what all will challenge, Epithites not of the fair, but woman, meer Titles due by custome and long use, nor can they be denyed without breach of Civility: Although I must confesse sometimes, I give them with as much regret as when I call some base poor spirited thing Right Honourable.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, in my mind, a very ingenuous confession.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: She were as fond that would believe them, as if she should give credit to her Mercer; meet words of course, a tone the tongue must run in for fashions sake.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Say you so? I have then so little hope to make you see your fault, that I will spend no more time about it. Your servant Sir, I must be going a little way. She • ffers to go out, he pulls her back.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.p: Nay deare Lady, I had as good part from my better Angel.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: What? these are your words of course? Pray let me go.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Nay, but in earnest Lady, you are the only party of all the world, in whose enjoyment I could think all happinesse confin'd.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: She were as fond that would belive.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Slid, what shall I do now?— Believe, do you say Lady? O could you but look into my thoughts: the tortured wretch speaks not a truth more credible; the latest breath of dying men is not so sincere as what I say.— Believe me? it would question your Discretion (Madam) to do otherwise; it cannot but be so in nature; it is as impossible for you not to cause these passions in me, as for fire not to burn a matter combustible.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Language due by custom and long use.—

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: • Sfoot, what shall I do? she will outwit me this way, I must try another.— Aside.

Well Mrs. Crisis, come, the truth of it is, I love thee; thou art handsom enough in conscience; & hast a little too much wit for a wife; but I don't doubt but I should rule it wel enough: wherefore prethee keep no more fooling, but let the Parson be doing.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Well Sir, I will be as plain as you, it is possible you may love me, although the language you have chosen to expresse your love in, hath not (in my mind) a little prejudiced it. For my part, I do hate none living, nor will I forswear to marry you; but I must needs say, I am not yet quite resolved on it, in things of such consequence I cannot too much consider. Pray let this for this time suffice.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well then, if it must, I will leave you to consider until annon. You will go, to Hide Park as you promised?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I shall be ready to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: In the mean time, let this make you think of me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Welbred.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: 'Tis but a trifle. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: As when a close besieged Town, opening a secret Sally Port to receive some scouting Spies, in rushes the pursuing enemy, and they with their Intelligence receive their ruine: So I, through my too inquisitive ear have let in that which cuts me to the heart. O Welbred! did I but know thee to be made miserable? Or should I have been more wretched in not knowing thee? It is impossible she should withstand a fresh assault; this Journey to Hide Park will end the business, and begin my wo.— But shall I like some neglected wretch, left on an unknown shore, only look and stare after my happinesse, that with full gale is flying from me? Can there be nothing done, but to prevent this present threatning mischief? O what? What shall I do?

Stay,—that would go nigh to do it, if not, it will however be a handsom way to discover my affection, which custom hath made (in me) immodesty to do.—it wil be an odd kind of thing though; It is no matter, even nature bids us shun a present danger, though we future hazards run. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Lagul and Mrs▪ Bud, Mrs. Crisis standing at the other door, beckens to Lovewit, to the end that she should come and hear what thty say.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: What (Madam) is it a Massacre resolv'd, is killing one by one grown tedious sport? Aglaura Scen. 3. Act. 1.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Did ever poor Sir Iohn think thus to be abused?

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: Really Sir, it pleaseth you to speak far beyond my deserts.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: O God, Madam, your Deserts are far transcending whatsoever I can say, Divinity inhabits in your face, and your cheeks contain the Elixar of all perfection.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: I am confident Sir, it pleaseth you to say so.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Madam, I should esteem my self incomparably felicitous, if you would vouchsafe to honour me this Afternoon with your company to Hide Park, and grace my Coach with your transcendent beauty.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: Really my company will be no honour, but rather disgrace you.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: I presume not so (Madam)— for your Beauty doth anihilatize all others.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Heark, Anihilatize, me thinks it is a pretty word.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It is a great deal of pity it should signifie nothing.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: For by this fair hand, Madam—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: He is almost spent, I know by his beginning to toy with her,— I will go and relieve him. She goeth to him with Crisis.
Monsieur Lagul, your servant; What? making new Conquests? Have you no pity on our Sex? If you go on thus, we shall look on you as on some common threatning mischief that will destroy us all.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: It is my eternal felicity Madam,—But I presume.—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You do indeed, to forget your old friends; What was the matter, I pray, we did not see you in the Country according to your promise?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Really, Madam, I did ruminate in my thoughts to kiss your hands, but fortune was not so propitious to me as to favour me with that felicity.—

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: It favoured her I am sure. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why what was the matter?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: I must confess (Madam) there hath an accident or two fallen out of late, that hath taken me up, and made me extremely uncivil in this nature unto all my friends; I shall certainly be weary of these Duels in the end, if it be but for this cause.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: So, now he is in. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then I see men sometimes feel your wounds as well as we. But I pray beware left in the end we may all rue some unlucky thrust.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: These Duels (Madam) I must confesse, are businesses of danger enough; but that is a thing which he that values his honour and reputation, must not entertain a thought of.— But yet at the first, I must needs say, they seemed somewhat strange; but now me thinks they are nothing, I look upon them as a meer Exercise; I cannot scarce eat a Dinner with a good appetite until I have fought one: They clearly save me forty shillings a Month unto my Fencing Master.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Were I but now disposed to be merry. Aside.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But I pray let me perswade you out of them.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible (Madam); for he that stands upon his punctillio's, must needs run into them every day. I have fought two this we • k already, tomorrow I am to fight a third, and I look for a Challenge to another every minute.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why, for Gods sake Sir?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: I was yesterday (Madam) in the Afternoon at the Divel Tavern, there hapned to be some words exchanged between a Gentleman and my self;— as I remember, he called me, Empty prating Coxcomb: Upon that (Madam) by the rule of Honour I could do no lesse then give him the Lye; I expected then that he would have singled me out, and have wispered somewhat in my ear, but the ignorant fellow nothing but flung a quart pot at my head, and kicked me down the stairs.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why, was not that enough?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: No (Madam) the affront doth yet lye clearly on his side, it was so resolved afterwards at the Golden-fleece.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Me thinks that is somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not at all, Madam, for the Lye is the highest affront that can be given, and so is the French mode, for once FranÇois de Valois, the French King, upon an affront that Charles the Emperor put upon him, sent him a Challenge, in which he gave him the Lye; the Emperor refusing to answer him, the French ever since in Complement to their King have esteemed it the highest affront that can possibly be put upon a man.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But how came you off in the other Duels you said you have fought?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p:
Very well, Madam: for the first it was a businesse of nothing;
for at the very first pas I disarmed my Adversary, and I not seeking after bloud, but the Vindication of my Honour, was content to receive reasonable satisfaction, the acknowledgment that he had done me wrong, and so forth. Some body knocks.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Who is that at the door?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: But the other was like to have proved transcendently more periculous: for (Madam) I stood upon my Guard thus.— Drawes.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Blesse us!

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: This (Madam) is Prince Ruperts Guard,— He came ferociously upon me with a Passado or two, which I putting off, run at him just thus, as my Lord Shandos killed Compton.— Crisis squeeks

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Villain! Draw upon a woman!He takes away his sword.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hold Sir, he is but in jest.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: In jest!

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: He knowes it is against the Mode to make a quarrel among Ladies.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: The Mode, you Coxcomb!— Beats him, La-gul runs out, Know-wel followes, and presently returnes again, Bud goeth out after Lagul.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Well let him go, for he is an Asse I'm sure, and so he ever will be, therefore it were a folly for to trouble my self any more with him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He can fight I see, although he cannot talk. Aside.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I am not altogether of your mind; though the Gentleman (I must confess) doth appear absurd enough, my Cozen and I though, are not altogether out of hopes in time to make him a little more understand himself, somewhat I think we have done already.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: It is impossible, Lady, except you should alter the Fabrick of his mind, unbend its appetite, or give it new desires; for as long as the divine soul creating breath, is clad with different disposing matter, and cast in several moulds, there will be Wise and Fooles.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Sir, if he were a natural Fool, I should yeeld much to your opinion, but in my mind his chiefest unhappiness is, only to have set his mind on some odd fancies, which if we could perswade him out of, he would be (at the least) not ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Lady, 'tis likely you may know him a great deal better then I, for, I must confesse, altho • gh he be one that I see almost every day in the streets, yet of all men living I have the least acquaintance with him: wherefore (Madam) if you please to make my knowledge to be so far indebted to you, as to let me a little more fully understand him, I shall take it as no mean favour.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: That Sir would be a very tedious task.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A tedious task! Why, what have you to do, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p:
That question I think may not be unnecessarily put to a
Lady that is drest, and hath dined, as I suppose you have.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Well Cozen, if you will help me, I will venture on it then. And to begin, Sir this Gentleman (as I have said) although he doth appear ridiculous enough, yet in my opinion not so much by nature as unlucky chance: for as when some common metals will serve for good substantial use, yet if you strive to force them to more curious shapes, they only such rude draughts will take as will render them more deformed: So this Gentleman (had his courser soul but had the luck to have acted in some downright way, to have managed some plodding Trade) he might by long experience have understood himselfe within his Sphere; nay, have had wit enough to have got a good Estate, and through the repute of that, have been look'd upon by the world as wise; but this by his fathers industry being left to his hand, the common course of the world, unhappily doth fling him upon things fit only for more refined minds; which although he cannot master, yet some odde grudges and imperfect stamps have transformed him from what he was, nor can he be what he would.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So (Sir) that some laugh at him, some wonder, as one would at some monstrous thing; some, indigested vain attempt of Nature.

sp.speaker: Cris
sp.p: And first Sir, his Fortunes enabling him to keep variety of company; he hears indeed all sorts of wit enough, but that being a thing too subtile for his soul, naught stayes with him, but some few words and phrases, which he rudely plucking from that natural chaine that linck'd them with appropriating circumstances, shew very strangely.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Not much unlike (Lady) the relicks of those species, which (although in a methodick way, and by the discursive hints of thought are represented to the mind, yet) in a dream appear with casual consequence, the fancie making absurd contradictions, whilst at one act it doth rethink things treasured up in different time and place.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Right Sir; for with some conceited speech, he is your Servant; what e're you answer, on he goeth to what is next in h • s memory.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Me thinks he sometimes puts me in mind of the Discourse between Clarangeus and Al • idon, what e're Alcidon answered, Clarangeus went still on with the story of his woodden window.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But Sir, it is with Complements as with all things else, except they beget one another, they are quickly at an end.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: His tongue indeed like the Germane Clockwork at Bartholmew Fair, is wound up but for a season.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: You would take him for Fryer Bacons head, made only to speak some certain sentences.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: It may be so: for I must confesse, for the most part, he doth use strange, high, and conjuring words; nor do I think his face wants brass.
Conjuring! You shall have him Court his Mistris, as if she were a Lady in some inchanted Castle. to be won with certain strange Ceremonies and mystical speeches.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: When he i • quite spent, he is wont to cry, O Lord.— tel you, You are mel • ncholy;— but that we have almost laughed him out of; for now with some fond protestation, he will say somewhat, which in effect shall be only a denyal of what you say.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: A little better then the Canterburry Fidler, that would still cry, You lye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then he will talk somewhat of Newes, or of the Weather, tell you it hath not rained of late; some common places of the cryed up Wits and Beauties of the Towne, with certain formula's of censure on them all, may a little prolong his Discourse.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O • if a Horse-Race chance to be, it serves in no small stead, (believe me) it will keep him in good talk for at the least a week.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You know, Cozen, what a stir he uses to keep sometimes with Trigunnel and his Mare.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But that which is his greatest labour, and which most perplexeth him to attain, as the only thing which in his judgment renders him right Gallant and most complete, is the punctilio Discourse, the Laws of Duel and the Sword.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He thinks that if he could go handsomly through with a quarrel without receiving a baffle, according to these Laws, he hath done more, and hath got more honour and repute then e're Montross, the Sweden King or Scanderbag.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Doth Fury know a Rule? Anger a Law? Strange Tyranny is this, that thus doth passions aw! Great spirits know your wrongs, can you whose actions might determine what is Valour, whose looks might daunt a fashion, and outstare the Mode, whose names might make your deeds, though interferring • ustome, regular? Can you (I say) be governed by the paltry bylawes of a Taverne? Shall Honour, that Spring of worthy minds, that just Reward of Courage, Pains or Art, be measured by the dictates of a Crue able to degenerate the word, make it a term for Cowards, or a talk to busie fooles; a thing, a well tempered mind e're long will scarce dare own. As I have known a man whose spotlesse life would seem to question Adams fall, yet would he startle at the name of Godly, Saint or Holy. But Lady, I doubt I have too much interrupted you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not a whit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: There is not a quarrel about the Town, but he labours to get the exact History of it; he will tell you its rise and growth, who gave the first affront, and where it last did lye; together with the judicious observations of the Sword men on it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Then he hath strange Romances too of his own Adventures;
there is no Scout, Gazet or Weekly Intelligence will furnish you with more improbabilities. Captain Iones was but a meer Asse to him.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I, for yesterday me thought, he told a story that went beyond his wounding the man in the Air.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: What was that, I pray Lady?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why Sir, he said, as he was coming from Hide Park, there was five Bailiffes beset his Coach, which he routed; but with what do you think?

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: With his sword; what else?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: No Sir, it was but a Ladies busk, that he said he had in his hand.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A pretty Instrument, and much in fashion with him of late.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: He gives one (Hadland, I think they call him) fifty pounds a year to keep him company.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That is, sometimes to countenance him, and keep him from a Baffle.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Hadland! Certainly I have heard of that same Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: 'Tis possible, Sir, for he is one of no lesse • ame then worth, although his decayed fortunes sometimes force him on unhandsome shifts.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Is not that he you said to day Mrs. P. hath been so much in love with?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: The very same; he is one of the chief of our modern Hectors.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hectors?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: This 'tis to be so long in the Country; Do you not know what I mean?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Why I mean a certain Order, more famous then that of Malta, the Garter, Saint Esprit, or the Golden-fleece, a race of Adventurers, who, out of what strange humor I cannot tell, have usurped the name of that famous Trojane Prince.

sp.speaker: Kn.
sp.p: A Prince! a Pander, a fellow was kill'd in the quarrel of a whore.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.p: And afterwards, Sir (as I have heard) dragged at a Carts tail.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Believe me, a very proper patron.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But whether is your Cozen gone?

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: The little Gentlewoman, Lady, went out presently after Mr. La-gul.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Poor silly Girle! She cannot though but put me in mind of my own folly, for (I must confesse) when I was of her years, I did not a little admire this same Gentleman; but a little time did teach me more wit.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yet still you did retain him though—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Why such a one for some businesses, I will assure you, will not do amisse.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I must confesse, for a walk or such a matter he may be as requisite as the Satin-peticoat.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And, believe me, I think a handsome young Gentleman, his hair neatly curled and powdered, sitting beside one in the boot of a Coach with his hat in one hand, may become the Coach as well, and be as necessary an appurtenance, as the rich Scarlet Livery, or the plumed Lacqueyes; and for treatments and such kind of things, you do not know the pleasure such a one may do.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But Cozen, you are well enough served, for I have heard that he will talk a little mystically sometimes; what, do you think men are fools, spend their money for nothing?—

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, my knowledg is not a little engaged to you as to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Truly Sir not much, no more then it would have been to a day or twoes acquaintance with him.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: But (Lady) I had almost forgot, how stand your resolutions for to night?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: If you please Sir, I shall be ready at eight a clock.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Lady, 'Tis a thing that company much improves.—Wherefore if you please.—

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: I, I, she shall come.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, 'Tis well you used that Argument, for I must confesse, all that I can do in company is but to adde to the number.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: What must I say then? I have e'en pull'd an old house on my head. Aside.

Your further acquaintance (Madam) may furnish me with better Arguments; but, me thinks though, to help to increase a number is none of the worst things a fair Lady is good for. Well (Ladies) seeing you do intend to meet, I must go and take some order about things.— But stay, what shall I do with this same sword?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, if you please to leave it with me, I will see it restored.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: I shall rely upon you(Lady) to do it. Gives it her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: How now Cuz? What thinkest thou? What, is he a fool?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I must needs say, I was a little deceived in him. But stay, this Mr. Lagul is as fit a man as I could possibly have thought of, and my having his sword, will give me a good opportunity to crave this courtesie of him. I will go therefore and find him out as soon as I can. Aside. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p:
alone. Happy you nobler substances that purely do impart what ever images your minds do form, and ca • transfer your thought resembling species, without the abuse of this adulterating matter; matter that our souls doth dresse in such disguising garbs; Don't Education, Custom and long use disfigure us enough? A few distant leagues making us to stare at one another as at some monstrous things: Will not the state fucus, and the holy Varnish serve, with all Arts antick Wardrobe, but that each soul must wear a natural mask, and such improving glosses and allaying dashes, take from the nice sitting of this
clayie Suit. Some whose flashy airy souls (if by judgment grasp'd) like air come to nothing, yet meeting with strange happy accidents, with a slye fallacy deceive even sober minds; each action drawes attention, and each word regard; Their talk, though vain and empty, some odd, I know not whats, doth so become and grace, that the deceived fancy (as when one looks through some false mediums or abusing Opticks) cannot but conceit strange shapes of Wit, which else would not appear. But this same Gentleman, (had not his better Fortune enforced my notice with a little acquaintance) I had o're passed him as one of the common things of the world, but now, me thinks, I do begin to see a glimmering worth, though muffled with disadvantages. Exit.

div.stage: The end of the first Act.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: I Run him through the arme.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Who, I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: The Gentleman I was talking of that I fought with.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Cry Mercy, I had almost forgot— You were indeed a little interrupted in your story.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: I, did you ever see so rude absurd a fellow, to make such a businesse before Ladies? But that you protected him, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We have told him of his fault, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Had not I been more knowing in my punctilio's, we might have been the Town talk for this month.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He doth begin to see his Error.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: He shall else: Is his name Knowel, say you? And doth he lodg in Chancery-lane?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I think I heard him say so.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Stay, to morrow I must meet at Maribone Park.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What do you mean? the Gentleman hath sent you your Sword, and by me doth crave your pardon, which I did oblige my self to get.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: This is as base as before he was uncivil; what doth he take me for a foot-boy, or a Porter, that I should put up an affront so? No (Madam) my Honour and Reputation is engaged; I am a Gentleman, and must have the satisfaction of a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, I pray Mr. Lagul.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p:
O God (Madam) Honour is the life and soul of a Gentleman,
it gives him being, it is the very heart and vital heat that makes him act and move, and can no more endure a wound.— But (Madam) I must take my leave of you, for I have engaged to meet at the Horne Taverne at three a clock, and now I think it is somewhat past.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Are you going thither? You may then do me a small courtesie.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Madam, I do esteem my self incomparably felicitous that my stars are so benigne as to make me capable of doing you any service.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I had best to let you rest in that opinion until I have an opportunity to requite you.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Madam, I am your most eternal Bond-slave to do whatsoever you shall please to imperate.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am (Sir) so much the more engaged.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: Upon my Reputation (Madam) I do not conceive so.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So now he hath done. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: But (Madam) what is that you would have me do?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You say (Sir) you are going to the Horn Tavern,— there is a Gentleman there, one Mr. Welbred.

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: He that invited us last night?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The very same

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.p: He hath not affronted her, I hope, she would not have me fight with him. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Only (Sir) there was a Letter I brought out of the Country for him, I quite forgot to give it him the last night; but if you please to do me the favour to deliver it.—

sp.speaker: Lag.
sp.l: I am glad it is no more.— Aside.
'Tis my ambition (Madam) to be subservient to you.— But where is my Sword?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If you please to walk in (Sir) you shall have it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Come this is the fairer Room, it looketh towards the street.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: I, so it doth, we might have been here all this while.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Well, if this businesse succeed, now—

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Succeed I Will death succeed to life, the day to night? It cannot but succeed: 'Slid, old Oughthred never did demonstrate a consequence so certain, as I could this.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But if he should prove an angry boy though, be mortal and wound unto the death.—

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Come fear nothing, I'l warrant he is as arrant a Coward, as ever wore broad silver Belt.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Pray God he be.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: There is another Youth too of the same breed above, I dare swear, I do not think but much good might be done upon him.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: But prethee let us make an end with one first.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: But I wonder what Hadland ailes, to make us stay thus long.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: He said he would be here almost an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: — take his milksop pocky face, for me.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: That pocky face shall pay for it, if thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Shall us jeere the Rogue, and make him mad, as we use to do?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I have this night studied some new matter for his purled taffeta countenance.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: But take heed you do not provo • e him unto fury.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I'll warrant you: do you think I do not know the man?— But stay, I think he comes yonder.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: I, there he is, but I do not see the Gentleman that he said he would bring with him; Enter Hadland.
Come, you are a trusty Card in faith Dick, did not you promise upon your word you would be here an hour ago?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Promise upon my word, quoth the man! What dost thou take me for a Scrivener, that I should mind such things as words and promises?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: A Scrivener! No, Di • k, I do not think thou art a Scrivener: but yet I must tell you, thy face doth look not much unlike the blank side of a Bond.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Not quite so smooth, in my opinion.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Come you shall contrive no more of these stratagems, if you can look no better upon them.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: The truth of it is, I did a little disorder my selfe the last night.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Disorder thy self! Why? what didst thou go to bed without being drunk?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: At nine a clock without a Wench?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: No that he did not, if the Madam in Lincolnes-Inne-fields say true. What sai • t thou Dick?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why, I hope you are not my Ghostly Father.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: No Dick, I think thou lookest a little more Ghostly of the two.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: An absolute Ghost, I vow: had he but a Surplice and a Torch, he needs no Chalk.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Chalk!— he looks like any.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come out with all thy paltry old Similies, and then we shall have done. What is it, Ashes, tallow Candle, Greene Cheese?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p:
Well, Green Cheese let it be then, if thou wilt: but
if thy face be a Green Cheese, the Cheese-cloth was somewhat course.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Because the coat is so rugged.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Why Dick?— But what if it be a Candle?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What if it be a Candle! Was there ever such a question heard of? Why dost thou not kick him Hadland? he asks, What if thy face be a tallow candle?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: He will give me leave to put the case I hope, I do but suppose.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Well then, suppose it were a candle: stay— why then I say, it would be a Christmasse on • .

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: I, for it is all wrought crinckum, cranckum.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, the face is a face, and may be a face.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: It may be (I grant) when it is finished.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Finished!

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I, for yet i • is but rough cast.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, 'tis no matter what the face is, or how it looks, I am • ure if it had not been for him that ows the face, you might have both looked like Asses ere this.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: As we did the other night when the Sussex Gen • leman beat us.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Was not I the man, who when we were quite blowne up by those same City Rogues: And we had been in three dayes consultation whether we should turne brethren of the High-way, down right beggars, or hang our selves: Was not I the man (I say) that found out this same Youth, this precious Squire, of whom within this week we have won some ninescore pounds, besides the expectation of this business?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Well, for my part (I say) the man speaks reason, and ought not to be so abused.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Yes, one touch more.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Come, out with it then, man.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I say, if we had turned brethren of the High-way, as he said, he for his part might have robbed without a Handcherchief.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Why, prethee now▪

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: —One would take h •• face for a piece of Holland.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: It must be purled then.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, are you not ash • med to abuse yo • r brother Hector thus?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: You a Hector?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: What am I else?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: That wan pale sprightl • s • thing dr • w Pri • ms curt • in in the mid of night, and told him half his Troy was burnt.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: O Lord, why Dick what sai •• t • ou?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why this Dick sayes,— And first for you, you Rascal, Do you remember what you were when first I knew thee? a lean, starv'd, thin-gut, thred-bare Rogue, that had never a rag to cloath thy body, nay, scarce a body to thy soul: Do you remember where I found you? Clapt up in the Fleet for forty shillings, that thou owedst in Ram-Alley for chippings of bread and porrage, when thou, Camelion like, hadst for some dayes lived by nothing but aire, and wert just resolving into thy first principles? Did not I pay this dribling debt for thee, set thee free, and since have made thee the man thou art? I must confesse, I saw a good hopeful cozening countenance in thee, that did promise much.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Come, a truce, a truce.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: No you Rogues, since you have provoked me, you shall repent it. And as for you my friend, with you I have been somewhat longer acquainted, I think I knew thee in the late Wars, thou went'st by the name of Captaine, a thing could do nothing but drink and damne thy self, and run away, so monstrous a Coward, that thy prodigious fears were able to work upon the genius of an Army; And this you shall confesse, or else I will beat it out of you.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Well, hold, I do confesse here before my friend then, that I am a Coward, and thou art a terrible child of war; so thou wilt let me alone, thou shalt be no more Dick Hadland, but a furious Hector or Achilles, any thing what thou wilt: thy pock holes shall be no more pock holes, but skars of dreadful Mars.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Why Dick?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Characters of honour in which may be read full mighty acts of Chivalry.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Characters saist thou? 'tis some strange Oriental tongue; Stay, let's see, I think they are the Egyptian Hieroglyphicks.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: No 'tis Greek, for I think they are all Omegaes, Hadland.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, There is a Gentleman below would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: With me? I'l warrant 'tis Mr. La-gul. Prethee desire him to come up.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I will Sir. Exit Drawer.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: I must now vanish then. Exit Caster.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Stay, I will go meet him. Exit, and enters presently again talking with La-gul.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Will you meet him, say you?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What should I do else?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Will he fight?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: So he saith.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: So now you have made a fine business. Aside.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p:
Come I'l warrant you, Aside. Come Mr. La-gul sit down, here is a health to all our friends in the other world, you will remember
me to them all. Drinks to him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: You will meet him, you say.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I shall be posted else: And I shall lose my honour and reputation.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I 'tis true, but—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: 'Slid, you had as good meet Iove armed with Thunder, the sheers of Atropos: the dart of death it self is not half so fatal as his Rapier.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: The Sword of Justice strikes not so certain; no fore man of a Jury could breathe more sure destruction.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: If it be so, in my mind the Gentleman hath a great cause of comfort; fo • to know the certainty of his death, is that which many a good Christian prayes for all his life long.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: 'Tis wel you put him in mind, for certainly it is time for him to begin to forsake the flesh, the world and the Divel.—

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Some Ghostly Father indeed were fitter company for him then we.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. La-gul, I say, drink on, it may be your last▪— We will meet somewhere to morrow before you go, and sing a Psalm, and it will be well enough, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, but Mr. Hadland.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come Mr. La-gul, to deal plainly and seriously with you, you have chanc'd upon a man that hath not his fellow, I am confident in the Kingdom; he is absolutely one of the greatest Duellifts about the Town.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Prethee who is it, Mr. Hadland?—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: One Caster, as I take it, his name is▪

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Caster! I have heard indeed very much of the man, he came lately out of France.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I, the very same, he killed a great Monsieur there in a Duel the last Summer, and was pardoned by the King for the gallant service he did against the Spainiard at the siege of Arras.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: I believe he is fain to leave France now upon some such account, I have heard somewhat.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay to my knowledg he hath killed some of our own fellow Subjects, but that he hath had the luck to carry things closely.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: The truth of it is, the Gentleman is a gallant spirited Gentleman; but he hath one humour in his fighting that I do not so well like of.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: What is that I pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: When once he is in the field he will make the utmost use of all advantages, he never spares any man.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I have heard that very thing dis • uted with him diver • time • , but he saith it is the only Mode b • yond se • ; crye • , Vn enemy le m • indre.
But me thinks (Sir) that it doth not savour so much of magnanimity; true Valour sh • uld never think upon enemies in the way of fear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What should I do then, Gentlemen, in this case?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay, for my part, I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Truly Sir, your condition in my opinion is somewhat desperate▪

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: This 'tis, when you will venture upon quarrels when I am not with you.
Venture! I could not possibly avoid it, I did but deny to lend him forty pounds, and straight he called me base uncivil fellow; and told me I did not like a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I think so; could you expect any other consequence? 'Slid, could any man have been guilty of such an uncivility?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, to deny a man I never saw before?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: It was no matter, he looked like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Upon that (you know) I could do no lesse then give him the Lye, and so the businesse began. For my part, I thought I might safely have done so, for I am sure I saw a Gentleman beat him not above an hour before.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Beat him!—'Slid, Slur, what shall I say? What a Rogue is this he did not tell us of it?— Aside— In some cases, you know, one is not bound to strike again by the rule of Honour; as if I have given the Lye, or so.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No, there was no such matter here, for the Gentleman was at play with him, when on the sudden he told him he was a Cheat, and gave him a blow on the pate with a Candlestick.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: And did he do nothing, say you?— Pox what shall I say?Aside

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No, nothing.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: You cannot tell what new Mode of quarrelling he may have brought over with him from France?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Strike him! if there be not some such matter in it, he had as good have strooke fire into a Magazine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well then, I am resolved.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: How! Not fight!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Nay, now we have over done the businesse. Aside

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Prethee have but a little patience, Aside. What do you say? Will you not fight! Speak it againe, for I c • n scarce believe my ears.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I say, I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: What is all the paines that I have taken with you lost? Will you with one act forfeit all your Honour?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Honour! hang it, I am almost weary of it.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Do not you value your reputation?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I cannot tell what to do, it doth every day so endanger my life.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p:
Your life? Can there be a life without it? To live to be the scorn of men, is worse then a hundred deaths. Can he be said to live, that is not fit company for a Foot-boy, that will be howted and laugh
• d at, and posted for a Coward?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I care not, let them post me; it is but going into the Country for a while, or giving out that I am gone to travel, as you know one did not long ago in such a case.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: No, that will not do, for you would as soon avoid your own shadow as him, no troubled conscience could more closely pursue you, divine Justice would not so soon • ind out the wicked as he would you: 'Slid, 'twas but the last Summer he followed from France, quite through Germany, into Italy, one that he had never seen, neither had the least affront past betwixt them, meerly out of a generous humour, because he heard he was a man of Armes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, Mr. La-gul, the truth of it is, your Quarrel was not an hour old before I heard of it; and I being extremely sensible of your danger, began to think how I might possibly procure your safety, at the last came into my mind a Gentleman, one that is an intimate friend of this same Casters, whom I have some acquaintance with. And to be short, I did a little feel him, to see whether he would be a means of taking up this matter, but—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why, to be short, he I believe hath heard that you are a man of Estate, and he it seems hath had an ill hand of late, and is a little out of money, and so he thinks to take an advantage of this opportunity to request a courtesie of you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, would • e borrow any money?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: He talked as if he wanted 200.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 200 l. I cannot Sir by no means, you know how much I have lost of late.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: That is all one, he knows your credit is good; and if you should deny him this small favour, he is somewhat a humoursome fellow, and I cannot tell whether ever I should perswade him to serve you in this same businesse; and yet I know he is the only man that can do it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I could spare now some twenty pounds, what if I offered to give him so much outright? would not he rather have it, do you think?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p:
By no means. 'Slid, What? offer to give a Gentleman mony?
for ought I know he might take it for an affront, and then there would be another business.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: An affront say you! nay, I will take heed how I run into any more of these affronts; — But if there be no remedy, I shall referre my self unto you in this same matter.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I will do my utmost endeavour to see what can be done then. — But what quarrel was that you were a telling me you fell into this afternoone?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why there was a rude, uncivil fellow abused me; but because it was in the company of some Ladies, I let him alone; but I believe I must challenge him. —

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why, what was the matter, for Gods sake?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why this same Gentleman (I know not for what cause) on the sudden fell upon me, and took away my sword.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I hope not so: Would you let him take away your sword?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How could I avoid it, except I had made a quarrel before the Ladies, and that you know I must not do.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: O excuse me Sir: In your own defence you might.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Might I in mine own defence, say you? — That I had but known so much! — Well, but what is to be done as the case now stands?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: As the case now stands, you cannot challenge him, for a man in Honour is supposed to have but one sword.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That is pritty, I vow. — That I could but think on these things my self! — But he hath restored me to my sword again.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay, then you must, for he hath restored you to your former condition. — But stay, upon what terms did he give it you? What said he?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He said nothing to me, for he sent it by a Lady.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: A Lady! I cannot tell how that same circumstance may alter the matter. — Stay Mr. Slurre, here is a pretty case, a Gentleman is dis-armed, and then the party that dis-armed him, s • nds him his sword again by a Lady; what do you think of it?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: What say you Sir? A Gentleman is dis-armed, and then his sword is sent him again by a Lady?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I, that is (as I take it) the case.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I, that is the case.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Why then the first thing that will be considerable is, whe • her the Law of Honour takes notice of a Lady; for you know Sir all Lawes look on some persons, as in Iure nu •• as.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p:
But in my opinion, thereafte •
• s she may be qualified, the Law of Honour may take notice of her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: As how I pray, Sir?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Was there ever blood drawn in her quarrel?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: then there may arise a question, whether that blood were drawn in the field, or no?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: You say true. — This I see will be somewhat a difficult case; wherefore (I think) we had best to stay till night, when we may have the opinion of all our brethren.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, I see there is somewhat in these Lawes, if I could but understand them.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Somewhat doe you say? they are beyond what Solon or Lycurgus ever made.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: If you be not knowing in these, although you were more valiant then Hercules, you might be resolved a Coward.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Were Iohn of Gaunt now living, one of our subtil Duell Casuists would baffle him with a qu • rk.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Turn the affront up • n him cleerl • , in despight of his sword and buckler.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, I must leave you, for I have a little business with a Gentleman that is above. — But Mr. Handland, do you think this Gentleman would take it as an affront, if I should offer to pay • he reckoning?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I cannot tell, you had best to leave some mony with mee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your servant Sir, I shall think my self super-eminently happy in your farther acquaintance; and therefore I shall not be a little ambitious of it.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Sir, I shall prevent your desires.
I could wish that I had but the felicitous fortune to be any way subserviceable to you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I shall esteem it no mean honour to be your servant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Really Sir, I presume you think not so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Well, go thy way, God send thee more wit, and me more mony, as they use to say.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Mony you rogue! What would you have? Have we not now 200 pounds? Two hundred pounds! me thinks it sounds very roundly; but that we have forsworth it, we might go purchase Manors, you Rogue, Lands and Tenements.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: —take your Lands and Tenements, give me an Asse with a thousand pounds a year, ' • is the only revenue in the world, it comes in cleare without any taxes.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: But if we go on thus, I know no reason but that they should rate us to the poor of the pari • h for him:

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Such a lad indeed is a frank tenement that Plowden never dreamt of.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: A frank-tenement! A fee-simple rather.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Two or three such youths, a • I live, if I had but a mind to marry, were a joynture sufficient for a lass of a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why, there is another, just such a one, in my conscience, not far off.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I remember you were speaking some such matter to day.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p:
Nay, I have enquired more of him since, and I hear he has at
the least fifteen hundred pound a year, besides some good summs in his purse.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Such a one, my boy, might be worth our notice: but what shall we do to him?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Faith, e'en modo quo priùs.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Nay hold, all men are not a • ike: ▪Slid, he may be terrible and valiant, a child of courage and the sword.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Dost take me for a Fool or an Asse? Do you think I do not know mens tempers? He cannot in nature but be a Coward. Did I not see him the other day with a c • p buttoned up on one side, and a Feather in it, upon a horse with a g • eat saddle, at Hide Park? besides, did I not hear him to day talk of his Honour and Reputation?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: They are shrewd signs, I must co • f •• se.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, let it happen as it will, I will take the businesse upon my self; and let the worst come to the worst, he shall not have a child to deal with.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Spoke like a Hector, and thy self, brave Hadland.— But stay, shall I go call Caster, and tell him of our successe?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Hold: Shal we fright the Rogue a little, and make him believe he must fight?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: It will be rare, I vow. But here he comes.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: How now, my Lads? What is the matter you look thus sober? How go affairs?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Faith, e'en scurvily enough.—

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Why? He will not fight? Wil he?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Fight! He was ready to fight with us two but for asking him the question.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Fight, do you say! He was got, I think, betwixt two furious Armies in the heat of Charge: he thinks, he speaks, he talks of nothing else but fighting.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: In the while that he was here with us, but that we carried our selves discreetly, he would have given us twenty occasions of the Challenge

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I looked out after him, and I saw his Sword out twice, meerly upon some trifl • ng businesse, of a justle, or the wall.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: We have a great deliverance I think: for my part, I never was in the company of such a furious terrible boy since the hour I was borne.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Come▪ I am confident • ou did not your parts handsomly; you did not fright him enough.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p:
Fright him, say you! I am sure I made thee such a
dreadful thing, that I dare swear, hadst thou but heard me, thou wouldest have beene afraid of thy selfe this twelve month.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: But that was so far from frighting of him, that it wrought an effect quite contrary, in stirring up a noble emulation in him: he swore such a one as I described thee to be, he would go through the world bu • he would find out.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: He blessed himselfe, that at the length he had the luck to to light upon one, in whom his sword might find some resistance, or in whose death he might gaine some honour.
— Take you (Hadland) this was your doings.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay, prethee be not angry, I for my part did all for the best.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: The best! Hang you, you knew it could not be otherwise.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay, do not judge of a businesse by the successe.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What do you think I shall do now?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: In troth I cannot tell,— Now the matter is so far gone there is no flying off, you must e'en go through.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What? Would you have me fight?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Do you ask why? You know it is against my n • ture: fight (quoth you!) I tremble at the very word.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Alas poor man!—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, come, e'en fight, and if thou chance to fall, I will see thee honourably buried on the common stock.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Fight! What wouldst thou do else? Hast thou not lived long enough?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I must confesse, if I had been in his condition, I think I should have hanged my self some years ago.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Hast thou not lived to spend a fair estate, that h • th kept thy Ancestors in good repute for many ages?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Ha • t thou not lived by thy profane debauchnesse, and base cowardlinesse to help to sink a cause in which we all do suffer?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Nay, now you are a little too serious, Dick.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Hang him, I would I could say any thing that would mad him, for jeering of my face.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Nay, then have at him.— What dost thou live for? but to be a Moth and Canker to thy Country?—

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: So 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: To perve • t and seduce her youth?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: O that my heart would but give me leave to fall upon either of these Rogues.—
You dam'd Villains must you abuse me too?— But there is no tr • f •• ng in this matter; I must go see what may be possibly done for to prevent it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Shall we call him back again?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: No, let the Rascal alone in his fears until we meet anon at night.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Well, here is a Health to the Rogue howsoever.—

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come on: But you know whom we are to meet withal at night; we had not best to be too busie, for they are Lads we shall do no good upon, except we first drink them up pretty high.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Well, as you will.— But what becomes of your business?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: O things are in an excellent posture; what wil you say, if before night I have my Land again?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Well, Do but mark the motions, and observe consequences.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: But how can it be man, that thou shouldst ever make such an Asse of that old, wary, subtle fellow?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: You are deceived in him, he is not so subtle as you think for; he is as fine a dull and stupid piece of matter as you would wish to work upon: I grant you, for this many • ears he hath had the luck to be much imployed in his way. And although he never read Cook nor Perkins, yet I cannot tell by what conspiracy of the world, he hath been that way accounted very knowing, so that for this many years he has heaped up huge summes, and now I think is owner of some Two thousand Pounds per annum; through the repute of which Estate he hath beene lately made a Justice.—

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: For all this, if thou bringest this about, thou wilt bee more f • mous then he that cozen'd the Jew, the Jugler, and the Broker in Long-lane.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Well, do but go a long with me; and you shall know how all the matter is, for you have a part to act this Afternoon, which you must do before we meet them we promised. Exe •• t.

stage.hi: Enter Welbred and La-gul, Welbred reading of a Letter.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: What should this mean?Aside.
Well (Sir) you will be pleased to tell you • friend, I shall not fail at the appointed time: and place.— You are not ignorant, I suppose, of the business.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I say, I will not fail to meet him.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Upon my honour (Sir) I cannot guess your meaning, I was only desired to deliver it unto you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: You will know more then I believe; for certainly you are the friend he means to bring along with him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I the friend! —Really, as I am a Gentleman, I do not apprehend you.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: No? that is strange; why the Gentleman doth challenge me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, am I falling into another D • el?

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: But you say, you know nothing?—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Upon my reputation, not I.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Well (Sir) Your Serva • t. I m • st go find o • t what this doth mean. Exit.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, certainly in the end I shall be weary of this same Honour, it is such a dangerous thing; I am no sooner out of the hazzard of one quarrel, but straight I run into another; I cannot do anything, scarce move, or stir, or speak, but it is ready to bring me indanger of a Duel; one quarrel I fell into yesterday, another to day, and now they are drawing me into a third. Well, to prevent them, I will e'en take a Coach and go with my little new M • stresse to Hide Park as I promised her. Exit.

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.p:
Stay,— Whether do I go? If I fight, what shall I hazard? My estate, my life, my soul; for (as I am taught) I shall offend as well the Lawes Divine, as Civil: If I do not, I shall be wounded in my honour. My Honour▪ I, what is that? for I must confesse (the word
of late hath been so abused, that) I scarce can tell. However, this I am sure of, that each man doth naturally addict himself to make a choice of some way gaining a repute with others; in which, if he receive a check, there is nothing can more undervalue him; hee being supposed to choose that in which he most excelled. I therefore, being a man of that condition, that doth pretend unto a sword, must run all hazards, rather then be foild in that.
Now tis true, one that hath employed his endeavours to ra • se a same another way, might passe over such a businesse as this, and perhaps it would not at all reflect on him.

But these kind of men are not competent Judges of what in us they call rash; for wee shall see, when any thing doth happen that doth concerne them in the way they have taken for to acquire a value and esteeme, They will act things as strange and inordinate: You shall have a man made up of meekenesse; A man, whose life and doctrine preacheth nothing else but patience and compliance unto others; yet he will venture for to • end both Church and State, nay, tear the world in pieces, rather then yeeld himself worsted in one silly argument.
I must then fight!
Ha! What said I? fight!
Me thinks the word doth carrie horror in it; I may be kil • 'd, or (which is worse) I may kill.

However, 'tis an action scarce consistent with humanity; Yet, my unlucky fortune will force me on it; for were I one who already had satisfied the world of my courage, I might then perhaps pretend a conscience, yet preserve my honour.
But being as I am, a fresh and raw young man, whose deeds will be looked upon without the countenance of former actions, Conscience (I say) will appear but a lame and pitifull excuse. Exit.

div.trailer: The end of the second Act.

sp.p: SHee has an acute and handsome wit, a judgment too, not usuall in a woman, then which there is nothing doth more touch my fancy; and yet, Shee wants not that which we call Beauty, that most divine proportion, that doth so lively strike our souls.

Nay, I needs must say, this was the only thing which at the first put me to a stop, and would not let me pass her over, as other common things: But now, a more noble Idea doth so fully represent it self, that I scarce feel its force at all; Nor doth it move me, more then those trivial petty ends, which in my child • sh ignorance I have pursued, would now stirre me: Nor is this strange; for certainly, Beauty's chiefest (if not only) Empire, is at the first; but afterwards, it yeelds unto, and is regulated by what farther conversation doth produce. For, without doubt, had shee now all the deformity that age, or erring nature ever yet produced, I should make her my choice; and those impressions, that by the little acquaintance I have had with her, shee hath made in my mind, would so over-rule my fancy, that in despight of the world, I should account her faire. Exit.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Stay; yonder he comes.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Come, shal we go meet him?

stage.hi: Enter Wel-bred: Hadland and Slurre meet him, and justle him.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: Why how now Sir? What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: — Do you ask questions?Hadland Strikes Wel-bred.

sp.speaker: Wel.
