sp.p: I cozen'd, thou old doting fool: could you ever imagine any thing else?

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Hey da!

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Nay, but Honey, what do you mean? you are not in earnest, are you?

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: In earnest? Do you think I am not? could you ever be so mad, as to think that I in my heat and strength of yeers could ever do • e on thy dull frosty carcasse?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Do you think that I would mix my blood with thy cold flegmatick, gou • y humours, had it not been to raise my sinking fortune, • nd to keep me from those extremities of poverty, that did daily threaten me?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Oh I am undone, I am undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: And yet had my condition beene ten times worse, were I to be ty'd only to thy bed, I should repent the change.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: A brave Girle I vow.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: For I already do begin to feel those warme desires that thou this many a year never hast been able to satisfie.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Come, Master Know-well, let us goe into the next roome, she will make me blush' else. — Know. and Cris. Exeunt. As they are a going.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: What, are you going Sir, I hope now you know the house, I shall see you here sometimes, our yeers indeed would somewhat suit, and what ever we should chance to do, here is one must father all.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O impudence!

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O patience, patience, patience, I shall run mad else, mad, mad, mad.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Now Sir, my revenge is perfect; do you not know mee?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Mr. Had-land!

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I, Do you not remember how some seven years ago you took the forfeiture of my Lands that were mortgaged to you, and ever since have unjustly kept me from them?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O, I do remember, and confess this is a judgment, a Judgment.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I'le warrant her she is a judgment worse then either fam •• sword or the pestilence, or I am deceived. Enter Slur.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: You have wrong'd me, for I say mine was the first turn.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Peace, you whore! I will not hold my peace.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: What, shall I be called whore in mine own house? out you roq •• Mr. Constable, I charge you to turn him out.
Hee turn me out!—stir but one inch you rogue, and you stir your last. Drawes.
And now I say, you are a whore, and a most damn'd whore.
And Sir, nothing so much grieves me, as that I have been the cause of helping you to this same strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O Sir, what is shee? what is shee? let me know the worst, for I am prepared.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: That which I know of her, Sir, is this; I was first acquainted with her in the army, where I will assure you she was accounted a very necessary piece of ammunition, in some five nights, I think, shee would serve all our troop; since (Sir) shee has liv'd about the towne, no small sinner, shee has been as common as a Hackny Coach, and much about the same price, two shillings the first hour, and one shilling an hour after, as long as you will: shee is as prostituted as some moderne Workes, only they are spread upon the stalls in the day, and shee in the night.
Hold her.—

And Sir, if the knowledg of men be the chiefest wisdome, believe she is not unwise, for in them she is not a little experienced;shee will tell you (I believe) the difference betwixt the melancholy, and the sanguine, the fair, or the black haired youth: shee could perhaps from her own knowledg, mend the observations of Culpepper, or Aristotles problems, tell who doth afford most pleasure▪ the hot Italian, or the tough Germain, the nimble French-man, or the grave Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Why, you villain you, if through the frailty of my youth I have committed any of these kind of things, must every rogue tell me of it?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: On I go for all this — And Sir, about a yeer ago in this service, shee got a certain mischance, that you may guesse, insomuch, that what with her expences to the Surgeon and Apothecaries, together with the intermitting of her trade, shee was reduced to much poverty, and had incurred many debts.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Debts!

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I, debts of all sorts, from her Mercer to her Milk-maid, all which have been some while forborne through the expectation of your paying them.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, what shall I do? here Goos-quill, take my knife, I don't know what I may do else.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Believe me (Sir) you will have a very charitable imployment of it, you will pay many a pound that for a long while hath beene accounted desperate; but for you (Sir) many a poor man might have beene undone.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: This (Sir) wil be almost as good as founding Colledges, or building Churches.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: And although you build no Hospitals, yet she may chance to find you imployment for Surgeons.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: You may in time to come, repair and make bridges for your nose.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O thou damn'd perfidious whore.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: O Sir, she is perfidious indeed, if you know how shee has served mee.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O How, how, how? let me hear, it will be some comfort to me to know any body else that has been cozend by her besides myself.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Why (Sir) this Gentleman and I, (although for my part I must confesse, I do repent of what I have done) did much assist her in the accomplishing of this her design on you, for which in gratitude to us, and also in respect of your years, shee did agree, that we two should have a certaine kind of imployment (Sir) an ancient Roman office called Adjutores thori, conjunctim & divisim, execute per vices, or by turnes; And (Sir) by the bargain I was to have the first turn; but shee (Sir) not minding the premises, fraudulently and maliciously, against all equity, justice, and good conscience, and against the true intent and meaning of the parties, hath let this Gentleman —

sp.speaker: Goos.
sp.p: I that she has, I'me sure; when you sent me for her, I caught them both upon the bed.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Oh, oh, I shall never be able to endure: O give me my knife again, O give me it, I say.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: You had best, and be accessary to his death.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Well, I am resolved on it; I know what I will do. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Come, let us follow him, he may doe himselfe some mischiefe else. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p: Which way went hee?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Up staires, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Pate.
sp.p:
Go after him, for Gods sake, and see whether you can find him. Exeunt.
〈2 pages missing〉
with you. Mr. Constable, I charge you for to seize upon her.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: This is my reason; Discovers himself.
Was not I the man that married you?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, it is a plaine case, yours was cleerly no marriage.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Nay, then I see I am cozen'd.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: You are indeed, Sir, I hope, for we have taken a great deal of paines in vaine else; I am sure we have been plotting this same business any time this month.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Well, I do yeeld my selfe cozened, and am glad it is no worse.—

And now Mr. Had land, I see you have wit to get an Estate, I hope you will have wit to keep it. You are one, I must confesse, of whose good parts I have heard divers times, and you shall shortly find, you have no more then I can well afford you.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: And now, Sir, here the Gentleman hath made a shift to come hither in a Coach, that I was supposed to have killed.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: And here I do acquit him.—
I must confesse, I had a challenge from him; but going for to meet him, I met with some other Gentleman, betweene whom and my selfe there chanced a certaine quarrel, in which I got the wound.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: I challenged you! Certainly.—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, do not wonder any longer, for I will resolve the doubt.—

This Gentleman was this afternoon to go to a certaine place, whither, if he had gone, I had beene for ever lo • t; wherefore I upon the sudden, not thinking of a better way, sent him that Challenge in your name, only thereby to hinder his going,—for which, Sir, I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Which I durst warrant, if it be but for my sake, you shall obtain.

sp.speaker: Know.
sp.p: Madam, you are so far from wanting pardon for what you have done, that to you I owe whatsoever happinesse I do expect in this same Lady.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If, Sir, you owe any thing to me, I shall look for satisfaction only in this same Gentleman, for whose sake I did what I did.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: I shall be, Lady, so far from quitting others scores, that what I owe you on mine own account, while I live, I shall never clear.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p:
Well, Mr. Had-land, I cannot but blush when I think
what a part you have made me act to day.

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.p: Thou hast done that this day (my Dear) that will eternally oblige me.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you will pardon what I said today, knowing to what end it was spoken; for there is not that Lady in the world of whom I have more honourable thoughts, then I have of you.

sp.speaker: Pat.
sp.p: I am sure I never gave you cause to have other.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: How now Sirs? What would you have?
Sir, we come to demand your assistance against a couple of knaves that are here, that this afternoon have cheated us of almost a hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Which be they?
Here is one.—
And this is the other.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Have they cheated you, say you?
Yes that they have.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: What say you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Your Worship (I hope) by experience knowes, that such a thing may not be altogether impossible.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen will you refer the businesse to me, upon that condition, that I do please you all?
I, Sir, upon that condition; but we shall not be pleased without our money.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Why, then I order you to give them their money.

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: But then we shall not be pleased.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Yes, but you shall: for now I am resolved upon a design, which I hope will be as good as building Hospitals.

Gentlemen, by the carriage of this businesse, I see you have more in you then ever I did take you for to have. And although you have been wild in your time, yet now I believe you would know how to value an estate.
First therefore, as for you Mr. Had- Land, what you have gotten by this device from me, I freely will let you enjoy.
And for these Gentlemen, I will give them that which shall maintaine them like themselves without these shifts.

To be short, Gentlemen, I have an Estate and never a child, and if you henceforward do nothing that may displease me more then this your dayes work hath done, I shall not be wanting in any thing that you may expect from a father. What, doth this please you?

sp.speaker: Slur.
sp.p: Beyond our expectation.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: We, Sir, shall never be able to deserve this.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Come, come, you have deserved it already.

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.p: What strange accidents have hapned this day!

div.stage: Enter Goosquil, and Whispers to the Iustice.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: O I, 'tis true, I did not think of it.
Mr. Hadland, there is a Supper ready within, which I did cause to be provided as for my Wedding Supper; but since you have got my Bride, you must e'en take the Supper too.
Gentlemen, will you please to walk?

sp.speaker: Old Cris.
sp.p: Then here we do begin the round; tomorrow my daughter and this Gentleman say, you must be at my house.

sp.speaker: Wel.
sp.p: The next day after I do invite you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And I the next day after that.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: March then in, and as you your Weddings make, In the same order now your places take. Exeunt.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: Pag. 29. lin. ult. add, I am resolved. p. 29. l. 20. dele [!], after the word, Fight. p. 41. for Act III, read Act IV. p. 45. l. 4. after themselves, add with. p. 64. l. 29. after believe, add, me.
